document.masterDocTitle: Three new species of Entomobrya from Poland (Collembola, Entomobryidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species of Entomobrya from Poland (Collembola, Entomobryidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Figs 8 , 9 , 14–17 , 23–26 , Tables 1 ,
4 Type
material. Holotype , female on slide,
10 IX 2012
. Poland , Kasprowy Wierch , N 49°13’50” , E 19°58’59” , a mountain in the Western Tatras in the Carpathians ( South Poland ), from soil under escarpment, among and under stones
.
Paratypes : 4 on slides and 69 specimens alc., same data as holotype. Deposited in the Department of Invertebrate Biology , Evolution and Conservation , University of Wrocław.

tr.th: Character/Species H1 area (head): Mc number An2-An3
Labral papilla: 1, without/ 2, simple and smooth papilla/ 3, multispinose or with some projections/ 4, a projection chaetae like
Ant. vesicle: 1, no bulb/ 2, lobule simple/ 3, bilobed/ 4, trilobed
T1 area (Th II): Mc number m1-m2i2
T2 area (Th II): Mc number a5-m5
Tibiotarsi, smooth setae: 1, not present or only 1 on tibiotarsus III/ 2, double file on all tibiotarsi;
Claw, dorsal tooth: 1, absent/ 2, basal/ 3, internal teeth level/ 4, intermediate
Unguiculus, externally: 1, smooth/ 2, serrate/ 3, with tooth
A1 area (Abd II): Mc number a2-a3
A2 area (Abd II): Mc number m3
A3 area (Abd III): Mc number a1
A6 (Abd IV): Mc number A1-E1 (9 if> 8)
A7 (Abd IV): Mc number A2-E1 (1 0 if> 9)
A8 (Abd IV): Mc number A4-C2a (6 if> 5)
A9 (Abd IV): Mc number A5-B5 (6 if> 5)
A10 (Abd IV): Mc number A6-B6 (6 if> 5)
Mucro, sub-apical tooth: 1, without/ 2, normal/ 3, bigger than apical/ 4, smaller than apical
Sum of the differences between the new species and the other species.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 18–31. Morphological characters of three new species of
Entomobrya
.
E. emiliae
sp. nov.
18 – 22: 18, Trochanteral organ; 19, Labral papillae; 20, Tip of tibiotarsus and claw of leg III; 21, Tip of dens and mucro; 22, Manubrial plate.
E. flavovirens
sp. nov.
27 – 31: 27, Trochanteral organ; 28, Labral papillae; 29, Tip of tibiotarsus and claw of leg III; 30, Ant IV apical vesicle; 31, Manubrial plate.
E. kasprowiensis
sp. nov.
23 – 26: 23, Labral papillae; 24, Trochanteral organ; 25, Tip of tibiotarsus and claw of leg III; 26, Manubrial plate.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Additional material. 3 specimens on slides and 2 specimens alc. from the Połonina Wetlińska (
24 IX 2012
, N 49°08’58” , E 22°33’27” , tufts of grass near the ground level, Bieszczady Mountains , southeast Poland )
.
Description. Body length up to 1,4 mm excluding antennae. Body colour pale orange to greyish orange as in Fig 8 .

Body. Length ratio of Abd IV/III <4. Trochanteral organ as in Fig. 24 . Claw with 4 internal teeth: paired at 56% and proximal unpaired at 76% from basis ( holotype ), with the most distal one minute; dorsal tooth intermediate between claw basis and internal pair of teeth. Unguiculus lanceolate, with smooth external edge on leg III. Tenent hair as in Fig. 25 . Length of manubrium + dentes: 262 + 310 µm ( holotype ). Manubrial plate with 3 chaetae and 2 pseudopores ( Fig. 26 ). Mucronal subapical tooth similar in size to the terminal one, mucronal spine present. Measurements of particular parts of a body in table 1.
Biology. This species was recorded mostly among and under stones, approximately at 1900 m asl (Tatra Mts) and in tufts of low vegetation at about 1000 m asl (Bieszczady Mts).

Discussion. Superficially, this new species is somewhat similar to
E. marginata
, but it lacks transversal stripes on the hind parts of some segments of a body. Twenty Palaearctic species have 1-0-1 Mc in areas A3, A4 and A5 of Abd III, but only eight have 1-2 Mc on Abd II (
E. albocincta ( Templeton, 1835 )
,
E. boneti Jordana & Baquero, 2006
,
E. germanica Jordana, Schulz & Baquero, 2011
,
E. marginata ( Tullberg, 1871 )
,
E. pusilla Latzel, 1917
,
E. pyrenaica Cassagnau, 1964
,
E. schulzi Jordana & Baquero, 2011
, and
E. transversalis Baquero, Arbea & Jordana, 2010
). Further identification is simple if we consider Th II. Only the new species has 1 Mc in area T1.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The specific name is derived from the place, where this species was found for the first time–– Kasprowy Wierch, one of the peaks of the Tatra Mountains.
